question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Homework: The homework was structured very nicely in the way the a lot of the code, concepts, and work built off each other every week. I also appreciated that we were getting the opportunity to code our own FEM from scratch because now I have grown to have a good understanding of how these things work. I appreciate also you going through the homework at the beginning of lecture to get us thinking about the problems. 
Lectures: I would say that the lectures slides were dense in good material, this has pros and cons, but the pro was that I could always come back to the slides and have all the information for me there. I also enjoyed the recaps of the previous lecture. I also felt that the strongest lectures were the ones were we went into talking about the shape functions, quadrature points, and algorithms, because I could really visualize the goal with this concepts (for us to build an FEM code). 
Office Hours + Questions: The professor always did a great job at answering questions after class or through emails. They were always nice and helpful. Also shoutout to the TA from Thursday 4-5PM they were a big part in my success in this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Personally I find this setup more enjoyable than how some other classes approach labs. I would even go as far to say that the labs are actually quite fun to do. As for the lectures, Volker Blum is a very good teacher. He explains things very concisely and his lectures are interesting. As long as you don't fall behind on the course content you will probably do fine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was pretty divided between the first half and second half of the semester. In the first half, we focused on more of the analysis portion (Mohr's circle, Castigliano's, etc.) as well as some skills in the machine shop and getting to know the tools in Hudson. We also worked a lot with solidworks learning FEA and CFD analysis, which I hadn't used before. I liked being able to use some of the software that we had in ME121 and get back to the design aspect of it. In the second half of the class, we learned how to better use 3D printers and some of the electronics components. There were a lot of group assignments, so I also learned how to better communicate.

response_text: Failure analysis from static loading (FEA, castiglianos, VM diagrams, vonMises, MSS, etc.), fatigue analysis (infinite life, goodman, stress life, strain life), mechatronic troubleshooting (I2C LCD, encoders, etc.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze systems (static and dynamic) for failure and use that info to inform design. In labs, I learned to perform basic FEA and CFD in Solidworks and improved on my CAD skills. I also practiced my machining skills using the mill in the machine shop, improved on electronics knowledge and mechatronics design. I ultimately did not learn much new content in lectures though besides that taught in the last couple weeks.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In reflecting on my mechanical design class, I found that the instructor's approach and the course structure greatly facilitated my learning. The hands-on projects, such as building a diving board and testing its maximum force, provided practical applications of theoretical concepts in beam bending and failure theories. Additionally, the flash talk presentation format sharpened my communication skills and helped me convey complex ideas concisely.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Both Dr. Simmons and Dr. D did a good job at presenting the material in lecture in a way that was comprehensible and straightforward. I thought that the homework, though long and sometimes difficult, were good practice of in class principles and allowing for the development of skills and problem solving that was instrumental to my success on the quizzes. I thoroughly enjoyed the entire xLab project; I thought it was a great addition to the course and allowed us to utilize design skills in a course for the first time in quite a while, since most of the engineering courses after EGR 121 have been highly conceptual and are not always super clear without any physical representations present. I think that while it could be improved in a couple ways, the xLab was a fantastic project, and I think it should absolutely be kept for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Since there was a huge shift in the middle of this class, I'd like to address pros and cons of both. For the first half of the semester, I enjoyed being able to learn about FEA and CFD, and I also really enjoyed the Exploration Assignments which filled an ethical void I think a lot of engineering courses have. I also sincerely appreciated learning how to use the Machine Shop, and wish this was introduced earlier in the curriculum. However, many of the assignments during the first half of the course felt unrelated or even sometimes like busy work. In the second half of the course, I felt that was fixed. It no longer felt like busy work, and our very consistent project was very interesting. I loved how each lab built on each other. I would definitely keep the XLab component.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Becky Simmons did a fantastic job of facilitating our learning during her section of the course. It felt like Dr. D was more attempting to hit a checklist of topics rather than ensuring we understood what he was teaching. The homeworks, while of similarly difficulty to the homeworks assigned by Becky, took significantly longer to complete because I felt I had to teach myself all the material. There was a strong disconnect between the material taught in class and the expectations of homework. Often we weren't taught that material necessary to even begin understanding the homework until the same day the homework was due. Overall, the timing and material of the second half of the class was lacking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the new aspect of the course that made the second half one continuous project. I think I definitely learned a lot more by working on one thing for a longer period of time rather than a bunch of smaller unrelated projects. I also think when seeking out help, especially Becky, she was very accessible and helpful and if I asked her to meet it was definitely super easy to find time with her and she would help. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the idea of incorporating research into course work is smart and a respectable goal, but the class structure definitely needs some revision. The class felt like it was split into multiple hastily assembled parts. Not enough planning and iteration went into executing the vision the instructor had for the course. The lectures and dry and related to lab work only in the content covered. To teach this class the way that I think it was intended to be taught, I think the class lecture/lab structure will need to be abandoned in the future to introduce some sort of hybrid structure that gives students more of an opportunity to engage and complete work in class as opposed to trying to get things done during an hour of recitation at the end of the week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I learned best when we did practice problems in class, especially in the second half when the process was covered step by step. I also learned from the labs, because they required design skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Learning was facilitated through mini-challenges, weekly homeworks, quizzes, team projects and labs. I think the short homework assignments were helpful for my learning but the longer ones seemed a bit tedious comparatively. The mini-challenges were interesting but it was sometimes hard to see how they connected to the course. The quizzes were fair for the most part with Dr. Simmons, but Dr. D did not do a very good job estimating how much time it would take to complete the quizzes and had seemingly arbitrary rationale regarding is cheat sheets. The team projects and labs have potential to add a lot to this course, but they were not managed well throughout this year, leading to unnecessary student stress.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In the first half, I really enjoyed the flash talks and the exploration groups. I thought the flash talks gave a good balance to the class and I always looked forward to hearing from my classmates. I also thought the solidworks assignments were helpful in getting a better understanding of CAD. I hadn't worked much on solidworks since freshman year so it was a nice refresher and also cool to learn how to use some of the simulation tools. In the second half, I enjoyed getting to learn how to use the 3D printers. It was cool to see the behind the scenes rather than just sending everything to the colab without really knowing what is going on. I also enjoyed taking on the role of the SD card. I liked being able to contribute to collecting the data and actually getting to analyze it for the xlab.

I really enjoyed taking EGR121 with Prof. Simmons and I think it would be a benefit for this class to adapt itself to be more like that. The labs often involved troubleshooting random electronic components as opposed to challenging the understanding of course material. The final quiz gave about 10 minutes per problem in a class that often gets through maybe 1 or 2 problems per lecture. Lectures could be disorganized, and technology issues often popped up, delaying the teaching. These should be easily troubleshot beforehand such that it is not an issue in the lecture.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is a necessary class for the Mechanical major. The professor will make or break the class. I hope that you learn everything you need to feel prepared for Senior Design.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is very difficult to give any helpful insight about the future of this class given that it will most likely be very different than the current course. It constantly changed throughout the semester in every way including assignments, grading structure, grades themselves, content, and labs. The best way to stay on top of the class was to have constant communication with the professors and make an effort to be candid about when the workload was becoming too much. The assignments in the first half were way too many at once and hard to keep track. In the second half, the projects were consolidated however felt less applicable to mechanical engineering. Good luck!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely a lot of communication, try to be positive and definitely voice concerns if you have them. Its easy to spend too much time on this class and honestly its not worth it because its never ending.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I'd say to not take things too seriously if the structure still hasn't been ironed out. It's not that I don't value the vision of improving the MEMS curriculum, but at a certain point, not performing the way you might have wanted to in a course that instructors are actively experimenting with doesn't really accurately reflect your actual abilities.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Assuming the class is structured like it was in the first half, students should be proactive in their group assignments and be prepared to spend a lot of time completing the various assignments. Be prepared to do some outside work to keep up with content.
Assuming the class is structured like it was in the second half, students should start xLabs earlier in the week to troubleshoot any issues.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Personally, I would try to avoid this class if you can if Dr. D is teaching it. He seems very out of touch with his students concerns, does not communicate well (which is ironic since this is something that he harps on in class), assigns an abundance of work without realizing how long it is going to take, and doesn't teach very well in class. On the other hand, Dr. Simmons side of the class was much more enjoyable. While it was tedious at points, her general empathy towards students and the relationships that she builds went a long way. Lastly, I would say to utilize the textbook for this class, as it is a very helpful tool.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The year I took this, the class underwent a lot of changes, so I understand that it was difficult for all involved. That being said it felt that the amount of work for this class was significantly more than other meche classes I was taking at the same time. I learned a lot about practical engineering tactics, but it was a lot of work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about setting up free body diagrams and V-M diagrams in order to determine axial, torsional, and bending stresses. We then can use Mohr's circle to determine principle stresses and maximum shear, which can then be used to determine if the part will fail using various failure theories. We also learned how to compute the deflection in a part, and determine how the part will respond to fatigue.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Basic design skills project centered - FEA, CFD, machining, tolerancing, tool mastery, screw dimensions etc. 
Stress analysis - Castigliano's first theorem (strain energy), singularity functions
Static failure theory - brittle and ductile materials, Von Mises, stress elements, stress tensors
Fatigue and fracture mechanics - strain life, stress life, Marins equations, stress mod factors, crack growth etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was pretty divided between the first half and second half of the semester. In the first half, we focused on more of the analysis portion (Mohr's circle, Castigliano's, etc.) as well as some skills in the machine shop and getting to know the tools in Hudson. We also worked a lot with solidworks learning FEA and CFD analysis, which I hadn't used before. I liked being able to use some of the software that we had in ME121 and get back to the design aspect of it. In the second half of the class, we learned how to better use 3D printers and some of the electronics components. There were a lot of group assignments, so I also learned how to better communicate.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In reflecting on my mechanical design class, I found that the instructor's approach and the course structure greatly facilitated my learning. The hands-on projects, such as building a diving board and testing its maximum force, provided practical applications of theoretical concepts in beam bending and failure theories. The lab session allowed me to gain valuable insights into material behavior and failure mechanisms, bridging the gap between theory and practice. Additionally, the flash talk presentation format sharpened my communication skills and helped me convey complex ideas concisely.

I thoroughly enjoyed the entire xLab project; I thought it was a great addition to the course and allowed us to utilize design skills in a course for the first time in quite a while, since most of the engineering courses after EGR 121 have been highly conceptual and are not always super clear without any physical representations present. I think that while it could be improved in a couple ways, the xLab was a fantastic project, and I think it should absolutely be kept for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Since there was a huge shift in the middle of this class, I'd like to address pros and cons of both. For the first half of the semester, I enjoyed being able to learn about FEA and CFD, and I also really enjoyed the Exploration Assignments which filled an ethical void I think a lot of engineering courses have. I also sincerely appreciated learning how to use the Machine Shop, and wish this was introduced earlier in the curriculum. However, many of the assignments during the first half of the course felt unrelated or even sometimes like busy work. In the second half of the course, I felt that was fixed. It no longer felt like busy work, and our very consistent project was very interesting. I loved how each lab built on each other. I would definitely keep the XLab component.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Becky is extremely open and kind and easy to talk to. She makes herself very easy to communicate with and responds to texts so quickly which helped a lot when there was confusion with assignments. I would not have liked to take this class without Becky as the instructor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Becky Simmons did a fantastic job of facilitating our learning during her section of the course. She taught us the material and walked us through practical examples to help use deepen our understanding. Dr. D's portion of the course felt much more lecture style and less helpful. I found that while we covered a wider breadth of material, I understood all of it less. It felt like Dr. D was more attempting to hit a checklist of topics rather than ensuring we understood what he was teaching. The homeworks, while of similarly difficulty to the homeworks assigned by Becky, took significantly longer to complete because I felt I had to teach myself all the material. There was a strong disconnect between the material taught in class and the expectations of homework. Often we weren't taught that material necessary to even begin understanding the homework until the same day the homework was due. Overall, the timing and material of the second half of the class was lacking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the new aspect of the course that made the second half one continuous project. I think I definitely learned a lot more by working on one thing for a longer period of time rather than a bunch of smaller unrelated projects. I also think when seeking out help, especially Becky, she was very accessible and helpful and if I asked her to meet it was definitely super easy to find time with her and she would help. I think also doing more example questions during the second half of the course was helpful. i liked that in the first half of the course we had the fea/castiglianos in our team project which got translated into the in person aspect of the project where we had to predict failure modes. I also liked the machine shop project, as someone who had never been to the machine shop, it was a great intro to the machine shop and made it a lot more accessible.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the idea of incorporating research into course work is smart and a respectable goal, but the class structure definitely needs some revision. The class felt like it was split into multiple hastily assembled parts. Not enough planning and iteration went into executing the vision the instructor had for the course. The lectures and dry and related to lab work only in the content covered. To teach this class the way that I think it was intended to be taught, I think the class lecture/lab structure will need to be abandoned in the future to introduce some sort of hybrid structure that gives students more of an opportunity to engage and complete work in class as opposed to trying to get things done during an hour of recitation at the end of the week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I learned best when we did practice problems in class, especially in the second half when the process was covered step by step. I also learned from the labs, because they required design skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Learning was facilitated through mini-challenges, weekly homeworks, quizzes, team projects and labs. I think the short homework assignments were helpful for my learning but the longer ones seemed a bit tedious comparatively. The mini-challenges were interesting but it was sometimes hard to see how they connected to the course. The quizzes were fair for the most part with Dr. Simmons, but Dr. D did not do a very good job estimating how much time it would take to complete the quizzes and had seemingly arbitrary rationale regarding is cheat sheets. The team projects and labs have potential to add a lot to this course, but they were not managed well throughout this year, leading to unnecessary student stress.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In the first half, I really enjoyed the flash talks and the exploration groups. Both allowed me to learn something interesting that was engineering related, but not necessarily super technical. I thought the flash talks gave a good balance to the class and I always looked forward to hearing from my classmates. I also thought the solidworks assignments were helpful in getting a better understanding of CAD. I hadn't worked much on solidworks since freshman year so it was a nice refresher and also cool to learn how to use some of the simulation tools. In the second half, I enjoyed getting to learn how to use the 3D printers. It was cool to see the behind the scenes rather than just sending everything to the colab without really knowing what is going on. I also enjoyed taking on the role of the SD card. I liked being able to contribute to collecting the data and actually getting to analyze it for the xlab.

I really enjoyed taking EGR121 with Prof. Simmons and I think it would be a benefit for this class to adapt itself to be more like that. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class reviews topics that are important to interviewing for mechanical engineering jobs. General failure analysis is an extremely useful skill to have for such interviews, and this class does an effective job of teaching you what to look for in failure analysis (at least for static loadings).Unfortunately, there are many aspects of this class that prevented intellectual stimulation. The labs often involved troubleshooting random electronic components as opposed to challenging the understanding of course material. The final quiz gave about 10 minutes per problem in a class that often gets through maybe 1 or 2 problems per lecture. Lectures could be disorganized, and technology issues often popped up, delaying the teaching. These should be easily troubleshot beforehand such that it is not an issue in the lecture.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

We can take more time in lecture to analyze what is going on in our lab projects, especially afterward as a reflection, and use that time to better understand the concepts being applied in the lab.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: To whoever is reading the course evaluations right now, I am sure you are seeing a lot of "not-very-reassuring" comments about this course. I must say that the professor was not the best at teaching and could often go on tangents, making it difficult for students to follow his lectures. At the same time, Professor Chen is very bright and will answer your questions to the best of his abilities. He has been teaching graduate students previously and probably finds it difficult to dumb it down to an undergraduate level. I think the lecture style with printing out the slides then annotating on them is a good idea. I can tell that he puts in the effort to teach the course and he WANTS us to learn. He's not some sick professor who wants to torture us. Tests are fair and I like that there is only one midterm. I also like the closed + open book test format.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: No the instruction was not good and I would not recommend Dr. Chen to teach this class again. He would reiterate in class how he is used to teaching graduate students so he was not good at teaching the basics of Fluid Mechanics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Chen in no way facilitated learning in his classroom. Instead, he confused his students. He attempted to teach material, often going on long-winded side tangents mid-class. He spent more time computing basic calculus, showing derivations of the mathematical equations, than analyzing the fluids principles and content we were trying to learn. The material he did present often contained inaccuracies. After class, we often received emails with corrections to the lecture slides and materials to correct mistakes he told us in class. For example, for our second lab, he failed to teach us the material needed to complete the theoretical analysis and to understand the purpose of the lab until the day the lab was due. He then sent out an email after that day's class noting that his explanation and the information in class and in the lab manual was wrong and the entire premise of the lab was invalid. He sent out a new resource page before noting that a single day extension should be enough time to redo the entire lab. Overall, I felt that this class was more of a complete content self-study with instructor assigned homeworks and mandatory confusing lecture, than a comprehensive structured fluids education. The labs, run entirely by Pat, were helpful and felt relevant to the concepts we were supposed to be learning in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The labs were somewhat effective in facilitating learning, however lectures were not very helpful. I would definitely encourage keeping the method of asking students when office hours would be most useful so that everyone has time to attend. During office hours early on in the semester, the professor asked myself and a few other students what he could do to improve students' understanding of material. We communicated that the most effective way we learn is by applying theory to tangible examples and practice problems, however his response was "there isn't enough to do problems when I have so much theory to get through." I feel as though this is not an effective method of teaching and does not focus on what is important - the students being able to learn information. Learning the conceptual theories is very important, however refusing to show students how to apply it sets them up for failure in every other situation for their engineering careers. We would spend very long hours attempting homework and struggling to understand him in office hours because none of us were ever able to grasp quite how to apply his concepts to real world applications. I would love to put theory into practice, but it needs guidance.

I have never learned fluid mechanics before and there was so much new material, new formulas, and new concepts that I learned from the class. It might not be the most entertaining class I have taken, but I feel that I have learned something from taking this course (compared to, for example, ME 321, which is just a repeat of EGR 201 and filled with busy work). The textbook by White & Xue is extremely well written and explains concepts exceptionally well. Even if you never listened in class, you should be able to do well just by reading the textbook and understanding the textbook problems + homework.

Additionally, the lecture slides were filled with crowded information and often times was not clear. If another form of lectures was available, this would possibly help.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Again, I know this course evaluation makes this course with Professor Chen sound like a disaster, but I do not think it is. Read the textbook if you do not understand the class and do the homework problems. Ask the professor your questions after class and he will gladly help you. He is a serious person and may seem scary to approach but he puts in so much effort to answer questions. From the fact that he changes office hours to accommodate more students joining them and explaining important concepts repeatedly, he wants us to learn. Sure, he might not be the best lecturer, but he has good slides, gives fair tests, uses a good textbook, is on time, and basically does what you expect from a good professor. I liked the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Overall: Overall I learned the fundamentals of controls systems, how to represent systems (and their behavior), how to examine system behavior, and finally how to design controllers that could influence system behaviors (aka controlling systems)In more detail:
I learned how to represent systems in three ways:
1-Block Diagrams: how to interpret them and how to simplify them
2-State-Space Realizations: what an SS is, how to get a SS for a system and going from SS to TF)
3-Transfer Functions: Although I learned what a transfer function is before this class, I have never understood transfer functions or how they are used this well until this classI also learned about performance specifications of controller: What they are, what they represent, why we would want them, and how to achieve them.Finally, I learned about designing controllers with determined performance specifications and with different steady state error levels.

The grading system was definitely a bit weird (how you would go from an A+ to a B+ if you didn't meet the thresholds), but she was open to listening to insight from the students and adapted in a positive way to help us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I really liked that they were graded for completion and putting in a strong effort because that forced me to go to office hours and learn the material, but not to get overly stressed if I couldn't get it perfect.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I should have developed teamwork skills and design skills. That was not the case. Rather than the senior capstone design course this was supposed to be, we learned new mechanical coursework. This should not be present in our senior design capstone project!! This class is designed to a practical application course, our demonstration of mastery/knowledge. Instead, we spent three months having new information shoved at us. Some topics were covered in great detail, while others were briefly mentioned. Regardless of the detail of education, we were expected to go teach ourselves this material. We should not have had design projects, labs, homework, exams, and quizzes all in a senior design capstone!  This class felt like 2 or 3 classes all smashed into a single class, both in workload and content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class did not facilitate my learning. I felt that this class instead was attempting to serve as a weedout class. This felt unnecessary and ridiculous in senior year. I would understand this class in terms of difficultly and rigour if it had been a sophomore level or junior level class. But, treating a senior design capstone as a weedout doesn't make sense. If you want to teach content, add an additional senior year content class. But this content does not belong in the Senior Design Capstone. I think the options are to move this content to 321 or make a non-design class to teach this content in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class would be more intellectually stimulating if it focused more on actual engineering design rather than design theory. Another way it could have done this was by relating the theory to actual projects, which it did towards the end of the class with the guest lectures. The mini project was fun, but I didn't learn anything new from it and it sucked up a lot of time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The flexible capstone projects and 2nd half of the semester was well-run and engaging. However, I truly believe the "content half" of the semester would be better integrated into ME321, while leaving ME421/424 as a full year, design-focused course. Senior design/capstone programs across engineering programs are typically full-year projects that allow students ample time to fully delve into their problems. I don't think the current model of ME421 lives up to this idea.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Similarly to many other engineering courses, the analytical rigor of the class made it interesting for me. I liked the challenging problems and how the tools we learned in this class are actually used in real world engineering applications. It could be more stimulating if more real world connections were made and more real world engineering problems could be solved as example problems. This could be done through connections with people in the industry working in engineering teams.

response_text: This class is a reflection of the ME undergraduate curriculum which was continuously being rearranged through the class of 2025's journey at Duke. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I should have developed teamwork skills and design skills. That was not the case. Rather than the senior capstone design course this was supposed to be, we learned new mechanical coursework. This should not be present in our senior design capstone project!! This class is designed to a practical application course, our demonstration of mastery/knowledge. Instead, we spent three months having new information shoved at us. Some topics were covered in great detail, while others were briefly mentioned. Regardless of the detail of education, we were expected to go teach ourselves this material. We should not have had design projects, labs, homework, exams, and quizzes all in a senior design capstone!  This class felt like 2 or 3 classes all smashed into a single class, both in workload and content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class did not facilitate my learning. I felt that this class instead was attempting to serve as a weedout class. This felt unnecessary and ridiculous in senior year. I would understand this class in terms of difficultly and rigour if it had been a sophomore level or junior level class. But, treating a senior design capstone as a weedout doesn't make sense. If you want to teach content, add an additional senior year content class. But this content does not belong in the Senior Design Capstone. I think the options are to move this content to 321 or make a non-design class to teach this content in.

response_text: This class would be more intellectually stimulating if it focused more on actual engineering design rather than design theory. Another way it could have done this was by relating the theory to actual projects, which it did towards the end of the class with the guest lectures. The mini project was fun, but I didn't learn anything new from it and it sucked up a lot of time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The flexible capstone projects and 2nd half of the semester was well-run and engaging. However, I truly believe the "content half" of the semester would be better integrated into ME321, while leaving ME421/424 as a full year, design-focused course. Senior design/capstone programs across engineering programs are typically full-year projects that allow students ample time to fully delve into their problems. I don't think the current model of ME421 lives up to this idea.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Similarly to many other engineering courses, the analytical rigor of the class made it interesting for me. I liked the challenging problems and how the tools we learned in this class are actually used in real world engineering applications. It could be more stimulating if more real world connections were made and more real world engineering problems could be solved as example problems. This could be done through connections with people in the industry working in engineering teams.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I should have developed teamwork skills and design skills. That was not the case. Rather than the senior capstone design course this was supposed to be, we learned new mechanical coursework. This should not be present in our senior design capstone project!! This class is designed to a practical application course, our demonstration of mastery/knowledge. Instead, we spent three months having new information shoved at us. Some topics were covered in great detail, while others were briefly mentioned. Regardless of the detail of education, we were expected to go teach ourselves this material. We should not have had design projects, labs, homework, exams, and quizzes all in a senior design capstone!  This class felt like 2 or 3 classes all smashed into a single class, both in workload and content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class did not facilitate my learning. I felt that this class instead was attempting to serve as a weedout class. This felt unnecessary and ridiculous in senior year. I would understand this class in terms of difficultly and rigour if it had been a sophomore level or junior level class. But, treating a senior design capstone as a weedout doesn't make sense. If you want to teach content, add an additional senior year content class. But this content does not belong in the Senior Design Capstone. I think the options are to move this content to 321 or make a non-design class to teach this content in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Mini-project was not stimulating. It was just like 121 all over again. I feel like this class should've been two classes, one for the content (which was necessary, but somewhat breezed over) and one for the projects.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As stated above, the most stimulating parts of this class were the mini project and machining project due to their hands-on nature.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class would be more intellectually stimulating if it focused more on actual engineering design rather than design theory. Another way it could have done this was by relating the theory to actual projects, which it did towards the end of the class with the guest lectures. The mini project was fun, but I didn't learn anything new from it and it sucked up a lot of time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The flexible capstone projects and 2nd half of the semester was well-run and engaging. However, I truly believe the "content half" of the semester would be better integrated into ME321, while leaving ME421/424 as a full year, design-focused course. Senior design/capstone programs across engineering programs are typically full-year projects that allow students ample time to fully delve into their problems. I don't think the current model of ME421 lives up to this idea.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Similarly to many other engineering courses, the analytical rigor of the class made it interesting for me. I liked the challenging problems and how the tools we learned in this class are actually used in real world engineering applications. It could be more stimulating if more real world connections were made and more real world engineering problems could be solved as example problems. This could be done through connections with people in the industry working in engineering teams.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class is a senior capstone design class. Why didn't we do anything related to that for a whole semester? This is the class I hear engineers from every school talk about. The yearlong project where they got to hone their skills and feel like a real engineer. We just did exams and problem sets and generally felt horrible because of a work overload. If we could start a project in the fall through the spring like an actual senior design class that would be lovely.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class is a reflection of the ME undergraduate curriculum which was continuously being rearranged through the class of 2025's journey at Duke. We should place more learning on machining, and skills that we will actually be using in our professional careers instead of small projects. I would prefer if our tests were on how to make a good engineering drawing, and practical skills instead of difficult questions made to test our understanding of the content that we will likely not encounter after this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the three modes of heat transfer, namely conduction, convection, and radiation, and how it affects and influences engineering design considerations. Furthermore, I learned the fundamentals of real world phenomena regarding temperature, heat, and energy systems that were backed by empirical, semi-empirical, and theoretical findings. Finally, I developed skills in a laboratory setting, and in my opinion most importantly, I learned how much error is introduced from simplifying heat models to describe a real system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned about heat exchangers, how to characterize convective heat transfer using dimensionless relationships, and how to consider conductive heat transfer networks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me develop a solid understanding of the three main mechanisms of heat transfer: conduction, convection, and radiation. I learned how to apply these concepts to solve problems like steady-state and transient heat transfer using Fourier’s law and appropriate empirical correlations. I also gained strong problem-solving skills by analyzing and simplifying complex thermal systems, using methods like lumped capacitance for transient scenarios and calculating convective heat transfer coefficients based on flow conditions. Lastly, I learned how to design and optimize thermal systems, focusing on efficiency and practicality. This included improving fin effectiveness, calculating critical insulation thickness, and making decisions that balance material constraints with performance goals.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Nico Hotz created an engaging and supportive learning environment that made complex topics in heat and mass transfer approachable. His clear explanations and structured lectures, which seamlessly integrated theory with practical problem-solving, were instrumental in reinforcing key concepts. Homework assignments and in-class problems provided valuable opportunities to apply the material, while his use of real-world examples, like heat exchangers and thermal insulation systems, made the course content more relatable. For future years, I would recommend keeping the balance of lectures, problem-solving, and practical applications, as well as his step-by-step walkthroughs of challenging problems, which were particularly effective for building confidence and understanding.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The class taught me how to apply fundamental laws of heat transfer to a variety of applications, ranging from heat sinks to quenched models. The instructor particularly emphasized the importance of performing sanity checks on initial assumptions (ex: checking the validity of lumped capacitance with Biot's number) and final results (is this in line with literature and are the units consistent), which I appreciated. The biological heat transfer essay also afforded my considerable insight towards how to approach real-world heat transfer essays without guidance and the nuances of validating assumptions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Studying Adrian Bejan's Constructal Theory provided valuable insights into the natural evolution and design of systems. I learned to recognize and analyze flow patterns, understanding how they optimize efficiency in various contexts. Additionally, Bejan's emphasis on hierarchical structures deepened my understanding of design principles in both natural and engineered systems. Most importantly, I acquired practical skills in applying Constructal Theory to real-world problems, enabling me to approach complex issues with a systematic and analytical mindset, leading to innovative solutions across different fields.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
This course fills a void in the duke mechanical engineering curricula. After taking this course you will 100% design better parts This course is great for the following reasons:1. Excellent interview preparation course; many of the topics are asked about in all mechanical engineering interviews
2. Having a "intuition" (deep understanding) about the stiffness of structures makes you a better engineer and designer. Knowing when, where, and how to add stiffener ribs or parts is a critical part of being a mechanical engineer. Coupled with the emphasis of material properties, this is the quickest way to become a better mechanical engineer. 
3. The homework assignments force you to get hands on with structure's stiffnesses (3d printing of frames, trusses etc.) this is an excellent way to develop a feel for designing and analyzing larger structures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a whole host of content I had no prior knowledge in previously. I learned the principles behind AFM, how piezos work to move machines at a nano-scale, how a cantilever is calibrated, how pulling experiments generate force vs extension peaks and how to analyze those peaks, the characteristics curves for proteins like titin, ssDNA, dsDNA, and sugars, and magnetic and optical tweezers. Before this class, I would not have been able to read an AFM paper and understood more than 30% of it. Now I feel confident that I would be able to understand 70-80% on first read and 100% if I put in the effort to look up terms I don't know.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Every single engineer at Duke should take this course. I am disappointed in Duke's lack of sustenance-based learning but this class has changed the script for me. We should be learning these skills during our sophomore or early junior year but alas you must seek out this invaluable knowledge on your own. Dr. Guilleminot may be the best engineering professor I have had. He seems to be thriving as a researcher but never lets that time commitment get in the way of being an outstanding teacher and mentor. Lectures are hard to understand. Go over the slides and ask for help!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained significant insight from this course - both concrete technical skills, and new mindsets for approaching numerical problems. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me the fundamentals of the the Finite Element Method. This included the discretization of a given area and the definition of its boundary conditions, the importance of shape functions and how they allow for the determination of the value of a given function over a given area, and most importantly how the method can be generalized from a 1D case to multiple dimensions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the code-heaviness of the class was fantastic. It is much easier to understand something when you have to specifically tell the computer how to do it. Dr. Scovazzi was extremely helpful in making himself available for questions with homeworks, often times opening his schedule quite a bit. There were multiple times during the class when I was struggling with a homework and he took the time to break it down into extreme baby steps to allow my pea brain to understand. I am very appreciative of that.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Homework: The homework was structured very nicely in the way the a lot of the code, concepts, and work built off each other every week. I also appreciated that we were getting the opportunity to code our own FEM from scratch because now I have grown to have a good understanding of how these things work. I appreciate also you going through the homework at the beginning of lecture to get us thinking about the problems. 
Lectures: I would say that the lectures slides were dense in good material, this has pros and cons, but the pro was that I could always come back to the slides and have all the information for me there. I also enjoyed the recaps of the previous lecture. I also felt that the strongest lectures were the ones were we went into talking about the shape functions, quadrature points, and algorithms, because I could really visualize the goal with this concepts (for us to build an FEM code). 
Office Hours + Questions: The professor always did a great job at answering questions after class or through emails. They were always nice and helpful. Also shoutout to the TA from Thursday 4-5PM they were a big part in my success in this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be aware that this course is perhaps 85% math, 15% algorithm design; I would not peg this as a standard engineering course, more so a course about a mathematical framework which is very useful to engineering. You certainly don't need to take this to use industrial FEA software - but this course is foundationally important for anyone aiming to do research in finite elements. I highly recommend it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand that the math behind the application is very dense and that if you lack both a background in coding and mathematics it is likely you will struggle with the course content. Having a background in either one however, makes the course manageable and achievable. There is almost no busywork and all applications directly contribute to your learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Since this is my second thermodynamics course, first being in undergraduate the biggest learning has been in understanding the fundamentals of thermodynamics extremely well and then building complexities afterwards. In the aforementioned thermo course that I took 4 years ago, these fundamentals weren't emphasized or simplified in the way Prof. Bejan did. I can now look at thermodynamic systems and easily identify how the discipline fundamentals like first and second law apply.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a deep appreciation for the historical aspect of thermodynamics that gave rise to our current understanding of the discipline. I also gained a greater intuitive understanding of thermodynamics and feel better able to approach a broad array of problems rather than simply being able to plug in numbers from steam tables.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned advanced ways of thinking about not just thermodynamics but also the world. The class was not only just brute forced thermodynamics work but also included a roadmap of scholars who lead us to what we know today as well as novel ways of visualizing thermodynamic concepts which are usually difficult to think through

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. One of the biggest ways of thinking I learned in this course was how to apply the two fundamental thermodynamics laws and apply them to countless different scenarios and problems. By starting with those two equations, I was able to determine so many different values and equations for numerous situations.
2. Many of my previous thermodynamics work was based on solving math equations, but this course allowed me to symbolic represent systems and determine equations through equation manipulation and not just plugging in numbers.
3. I learned that when designing a system or adding a problem, the idea of "adding zero" is a very useful concept. Bejan applied the idea that it is your system you are designing or evaluating and can add zero with your assumptions to determine the state/equations of a system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Professor Bejan is arguably the most captivating lecturer I've ever taken a class with. I gained a strong understanding for the fundamental principles behind thermodynamic laws and relations which strengthens my understanding of power and refrigeration applications. This strongly improved my ability to think through power and heat transfer problems and evaluate tradeoffs in thermodynamic device design. Beyond the direct course materials, Prof. Bejan also placed a strong emphasis on and encouraged students to study and learn from history as well as develop a questioning attitude to think critically through all aspects of engineering problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I developed understanding of concept and application of the first and second law in open and closed systems, aggregated systems, and cycles.
2. I developed skill in sketching simplified thermodynamic systems, such as power cycles and refrigeration cycles.
3. I acquired some understanding in fundamental of power plant design and the design parameters' relationship to economic benefits.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I felt uniquely privileged to study under Professor Bejan because, in his extensive knowledge of foreign languages, he read breakthrough texts of pioneers in the field of thermodynamics like Sardi Carnot in French written in the 1800's. He then teaches us from the premises of these texts, distilling what would be appropriate for a 500-level graduate course. This is unlike any other course I have ever taken. I also appreciated his measured pacing through course fundamentals, sometimes even slowing down on key lectures which in turn helped us grasp the higher ones better.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Bejan is an exceptional lecturer. Lectures were engaging and informative, leaving me more educated on both history and engineering. I wouldn't change much about Professor Bejan's lectures, other than including an additional example on occasion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In BIOMEDICAL MICROSYSTEMS, I developed a strong foundation in microfabrication techniques, specifically photolithography and soft lithography, which are essential for designing and building microscale biomedical devices. I also gained practical knowledge in system integration—learning how microfluidics, electronics, and sensors can be combined in compact devices to monitor or manipulate biological samples. The most important thing I learn in this course is that the course introduced me to a new way of thinking about microsystems and engineering at the biological application

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the Biomedical Microsystem course, I gained foundational knowledge in photolithography and soft lithography techniques. I learned how to use photoresists, mask aligners, and UV exposure systems to transfer micro-scale patterns onto substrates. I also explored soft lithography methods such as microcontact printing and PDMS molding, which are widely used in fabricating flexible and biocompatible microfluidic devices.I developed the ability to apply scaling laws to analyze microscale phenomena. This included understanding how parameters like surface area-to-volume ratio and Reynolds number affect fluid flow and heat transfer at small scales. These principles helped me evaluate and design microdevices with greater accuracy and predictability.Lastly, I adopted a systems-thinking approach to biomedical device design. By integrating engineering principles with biological needs and fabrication constraints, I learned to evaluate the feasibility and functionality of microdevices in real-world applications. This perspective emphasized the importance of interdisciplinary thinking in solving complex biomedical challenges.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In ME-535-01: Biomedical Microsystems with Professor Tony Huang, I developed a whole new way of thinking about how engineering can intersect with biology on a microscale. One of the most fascinating parts was learning how fluids behave differently at such small scales something that’s so counterintuitive but critical when designing devices like lab-on-a-chip systems. I also got hands-on exposure to micropatterning techniques, which showed me how we can guide cell behavior or create tiny environments for biomedical research. But what stood out the most was understanding how BioMEMS devices are designed and how they can be used to solve real healthcare problems. It gave me a big-picture view of how mechanical and electrical systems can be combined with biology to create meaningful, life-changing technologies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend this course to 1st year master's students or undergrads who are interested in med devices. I think this course offers a good crash course. I do not think that this course should be required if you have taken Design Health. This course is similar but much less in-depth because Design Health is 3 semesters.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be aware that this class will require a significant dedication of time outside of class because in addition to near-weekly homework, you will need to meet regularly with your project group, work on those three projects on your own, conduct clinician interviews, and shadow (including a long clearance process). If you aren't able to dedicate sufficient time to complete the course requirements well, I don't think you'll be able to get much out of the course. You should also be aware that the vast majority of the course content is applicable to medical device development in general, and not specific to surgical technologies or medical robotics (beyond a few lectures discussing appropriate applications of automation in medicine and the Da Vinci surgical robot).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
One of the most critical skills I developed in this course was the ability to digest information provided by clinicians in either a lecture room or operating environment. This skill is critical in developing an understanding of the problems currently faced in the medical field.
Another key insight I learned in this course is the approach required for pitches to investors for new medical technologies. Specifically, in project 2 I learned a lot about effective communication strategies to different investing parties when pitching a product.
Finally, I felt like I had very little insight into the grant proposal side of medtech prior to this course. Following the final project, I feel like I have started to understand the fundamentals of applying for grants as well as the development of technological significant and innovative research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to identify problems in surgery through first-person interaction, listening to experts, and conducting a literature review. I learned how to prototype a medical device meant for a surgical application based on that identified problem. I have also learned about the various funding opportunities and necessary litigation to take into account when building a device/ company in the space.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
One of the most critical skills I developed in this course was the ability to digest information provided by clinicians in either a lecture room or operating environment. This skill is critical in developing an understanding of the problems currently faced in the medical field.
Another key insight I learned in this course is the approach required for pitches to investors for new medical technologies. Specifically, in project 2 I learned a lot about effective communication strategies to different investing parties when pitching a product.
Finally, I felt like I had very little insight into the grant proposal side of medtech prior to this course. Following the final project, I feel like I have started to understand the fundamentals of applying for grants as well as the development of technological significant and innovative research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to identify problems in surgery through first-person interaction, listening to experts, and conducting a literature review. I learned how to prototype a medical device meant for a surgical application based on that identified problem. I have also learned about the various funding opportunities and necessary litigation to take into account when building a device/ company in the space.

response_text:
Despite my prior experience in developing ML models, I found myself taken aback by gaps in my understanding based on some of the class material which proved more intricate than I had anticipated. However, amidst the struggles, I did manage to extract valuable insights, particularly from the segments that focused on mechanisms of different classical ML models and handling time series data. Despite being accustomed to Spyder for my ML analyses, Google Colab proved transformative. My proficiency in using Colab increased tremendously which simplified the completion of assignments on time. Consequently, I have since abandoned Spyder and embraced Colab for my research after appreciating its convenience. Overall, while the course presented challenges, it facilitated significant growth in my skill set by introducing me to tools and work flows that will enhance my research efficiency beyond the class requirements. Thanks, Prof. Carlson!!

response_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment, Professor George Delagrammatikas created a structured and engaging setting that significantly facilitated my learning. His clear explanations, well-organized lectures, and use of real-world examples bridged the gap between theory and application, making complex concepts more accessible. The inclusion of hands-on assignments and interactive discussions encouraged active participation and critical thinking, allowing students to explore practical applications of the material. response_text: Overall, I would say that I learned a lot in this course and from Dr. Cheng's teaching and course lectures. As someone who is still very new to robotics, I really enjoyed how Dr. Cheng structured the course in a way where we had a variety of different lecture topics that each student presented - this not only helped me learn more about my own topic that I presented, but also about the various differnet topics that the other students presented.
