question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered a wide range of up in coming and interesting topics in robotics. I learned about math for defining contact points for robotics manipulation, reinforcement learning for robotic manipulation, and universal manipulators just to name a few.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Understanding how robots “grasp” the world
One of the biggest takeaways for me was learning how robots physically interact with objects especially how they grasp and manipulate them. Concepts like force closure and wrench spaces helped me see grasping not just as a mechanical action but as a balance of forces and geometry. It gave me a new appreciation for how complex even a “simple” task like picking something up can be for a robot.2. Bridging control theory with real-world behavior
I also learned how to connect the dots between control theory and real robotic actions. Working with impedance control and hybrid force/position control showed me how robots can be made to behave more naturally and safely, especially in dynamic or unpredictable environments. It shifted my thinking from purely theoretical to more application-oriented problem-solving.3. Planning in the face of uncertainty
Lastly, I really valued learning about planning under uncertainty. Techniques like sampling-based planning and optimization-based trajectories helped me think more algorithmically and realistically about how robots navigate complex spaces. It taught me that robotics is as much about smart decision-making as it is about mechanics or electronics.

response_text:
1. Through both lectures and student-led presentations, I developed a strong foundation in classic and current research on robotic manipulation. Reading and discussing technical papers helped me better understand how academic research is structured and how ideas in robotics evolve over time.
2. The in-class presentation pushed me to deeply analyze a topic of my choice and clearly communicate complex ideas to my peers. This improved my ability to synthesize research and explain technical content effectively in both slides and discussion.
3. The semester-long course project taught me how to collaborate effectively on a research idea, from proposal to execution. Presenting our progress at different stages also helped build project management and critical thinking skills, which are essential for both academic and industry settings.

Overall, I would say that this has been one of my favorite courses at Duke so far, and Dr. Cheng has really been one of a kind! I think that Duke is very lucky to have her!

response_text: What made this class so intellectually stimulating was the perfect blend of theory, application, and open-ended exploration. The concepts we covered like grasp planning, motion control, and planning under uncertainty weren’t just presented as equations or algorithms, but as tools to solve real, complex problems in robotics. That made every lecture feel meaningful and intellectually rewarding.The assignments and discussions encouraged me to think beyond the textbook to ask why certain approaches work, how they could be improved, and where they’re used in real-world robotic systems. I especially appreciated the emphasis on connecting mathematical models with physical intuition, which helped deepen my critical thinking.If anything were to make it even more stimulating, perhaps occasional guest lectures from researchers or industry professionals could add new perspectives and show how these ideas are actively shaping the field. But overall, the course already struck a great balance between rigor and inspiration.

response_text: Intermolecular interactions, polymer thermodynamics, dynamic light scattering. And how to characterize polymers to get useful information

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how soft materials are classified into polymers, colloids, amphiphiles, liquid crystals, and biological systems, and how these categories often overlap. I gained insight into the self-assembly behavior of amphiphiles, such as surfactants and lipids, and the formation of lyotropic liquid crystal phases. The course also helped me understand the thermally driven transitions in thermotropic liquid crystals. I developed the ability to connect fundamental physical chemistry concepts with practical applications, such as in foods and detergents. Overall, I learned to think about soft matter from both a molecular and functional perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Classification of soft matter, fundamental theory, and physics underlying the observable properties of soft matter materials, characterization techniques and data interpretation to understand the material physical properties & potential application in various fields

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. There are many different printing techniques beyond FDM which we initially think of. These can be used in different scenarios to benefit a product. This class helped give me key skills to be able to recognize when a technique might be useful. 
2. I gained new 3D printing technical skills - during the project I learned how to edit meshes and use CAD to create assemblies. I also learned to use Cura which has been helpful in other classes. 
3. I learned that 3D printing is becoming more and more popular in large-scale applications. This is exciting but reminds us how important it is to make sure we use 3D printing when needed but choose other techniques when they are better suited for a task.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1.	I gained a deeper understanding of STEM and learned about some of the newest in situ STEM tools and research. I found it fascinating that in situ STEM can study changes at the atomic level.
2.	I learned that STEM combined with EDX or EELS, which are two techniques that complement each other, can provide a lot of information. Together, they help us understand element changes and atomic-scale reaction mechanisms.
3.	4D-STEM can collect full information from both real space (x, y) and reciprocal space (x, y), so we can get nearly complete data from it, which is amazing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. SEM technique
2. Microscope mechanism
3. Application

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Basics of optics in scanning transmission electron microscopes and TEMs, including a lot about aberration correction.
2. Different types of measurements that can be done with STEM and what it can tell us about the samples
3. Different data analysis techniques, including machine learning algorithms!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 4D-STEM, sSTEM-EELS, DPC imaging...

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This electron microscopy course has been both intellectually stimulating and practically valuable. I have gained a much deeper understanding of how advanced imaging techniques can reveal the structure, composition, and properties of materials at the nanoscale. Here are three main things I learnt: (1) I understood the principles of TEM on the course, including knowledge of electron-sample interactions, contrast mechanisms (e.g., diffraction, phase, Z-contrast), and the limitations and advantages of each technique. (2) I learned the critical interpretation methods of TEM data, including adding scale bars and recognizing the zone axes. (3) I learned practical STEM simulation skills in the class. In the simulation training, I learned how the accelerating voltage, aberrations, and aperture selection influence imaging quality and interpretation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The teacher’s class included an introduction to the principles of STEM and the latest research frontiers. We also visited a real TEM lab. Guest teachers explained how to analyze STEM data, and researchers from Oak Ridge shared their research. There were many different ways to get useful information.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learned about how electrons are arranged in solids and the formation of energy bands. It explains the distinction between conductors, semiconductors, and insulators based on band gaps. For example, this area covers the electrical properties of materials with a small band gap (semiconductors). We learned about intrinsic (pure) and extrinsic (doped) semiconductors, and how doping affects conductivity. Besides, we have developed knowledge of the structure of crystalline materials and their atomic arrangement. It involves studying various lattice structures, unit cells, and symmetry operations in crystals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned that cavitation bubble collapse plays a critical role in stone fragmentation during Holmium:YAG laser lithotripsy. While photothermal ablation has traditionally been considered the primary mechanism, recent studies show that toroidal bubble collapse near the stone surface generates intensified shock waves that contribute significantly to stone damage. This understanding was supported by high-speed imaging and hydrophone measurements that revealed distinct damage patterns and optimal standoff distances for efficient energy delivery.I also developed the ability to identify key acoustic features associated with damage-inducing cavitation events. These include peak pressure, rise time, pulse width, and the number and timing of shock wave emissions. Such features help distinguish between effective and ineffective bubble collapses, enabling more accurate monitoring of laser-stone interactions. Recognizing these parameters is essential for linking acoustic signals directly to stone damage.Lastly, I gained insights into applying sound recognition and machine learning techniques to classify cavitation signals. Feature extraction methods and spectrogram analysis were adapted to analyze acoustic emissions from bubble collapse. Classifiers such as support vector machines, hidden Markov models, and neural networks were used to categorize signals based on their potential to cause damage, paving the way for automated feedback systems during laser lithotripsy procedures.

The integration of relevant journal articles and real-world clinical applications made the topics both accessible and meaningful.The course was well-structured, progressing logically from theoretical background to experimental design and data interpretation. The instructor’s feedback on written and oral work was constructive and personalized, which reinforced my learning and improved my technical communication skills.One valuable component I would retain for future years is the emphasis on applying core concepts to ongoing research problems. Assignments like the literature review and research presentation allowed students to engage deeply with their topics and connect course material to their own interests. This research-integrated approach not only enhanced learning but also made the course highly relevant and impactful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking this course, I highly recommend it, especially if you’re interested in biomedical applications of physics, signal processing, or laser-based technologies. The course offers a rare opportunity to engage with cutting-edge research while building a solid foundation in cavitation dynamics and acoustic signal analysis. You’ll gain valuable skills in literature review and experimental interpretation.The instructor is supportive and deeply knowledgeable, fostering a collaborative and intellectually engaging environment. The course is well-structured, and assignments are thoughtfully designed to connect theory with real-world problems. Be prepared to think critically, read deeply, and challenge yourself, but the experience will be rewarding.Ultimately, this course will sharpen your technical communication skills, expose you to interdisciplinary thinking, and provide tools that are directly relevant to advancing medical technologies. It's a strong choice for anyone aiming to work at the intersection of engineering, biomedicine, and data-driven research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: ME-639-01 : COMP FLD MECH & HEAT TRN.ME-639-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned some basics in FORTRAN, how to approach analysis problems using coding more efficiently, and some fundamentals for heat transfer and fluid flow analysis.

course: ME-639-01 : COMP FLD MECH & HEAT TRN.ME-639-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how Fortran handles memory in arrays. I learned about how to set up a complex Fortran program to run as a CFD code. I learned the basics of how an Eulerian formula can be discretized to have different stability and accuracy.

course: ME-639-01 : COMP FLD MECH & HEAT TRN.ME-639-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: ME-639-01 : COMP FLD MECH & HEAT TRN.ME-639-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a variety of schemes for solving PDEs, such as the upwind scheme and leap-frog scheme. I acquired skills in applying these schemes through Python. During later parts of the class, I learned about using the Fortran language in tackling basic CFD simulations.

course: ME-639-01 : COMP FLD MECH & HEAT TRN.ME-639-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Going over the code in class did help to explain concepts as they came up. This is definitely an aspect that should be kept for future years but perhaps tweaked in that the code is given out ahead of time so that less class time is spent typing out the code. It was also a good idea to go over concepts first before going into the code, so that we'd have some background about the concepts.
